unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Construction $2$ Proportion $z$-Interval: Fruits and Vegetables
question_text:
A nutritionist was interested in seeing if there was difference in people from the U.S. who prefer fruit over vegetables compared with the people in Canada who prefer fruit over vegetables. The nutritionist randomly selected $200\text{ people}$ from each country, and found that $136\text{ people}$ from the U.S. and $108\text{ people}$ from Canada favored fruit over vegetables.
Which formula calculates the $98\%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions of Americans who prefer fruit over vegetables to Canadians who do so?
solution:
This is a $2$ proportion $z$-interval. The formula for the $2$ proportion $z$-interval is:

$${ (\hat { p } }_{ 1 }-{ \hat { p } }_{ 2 })\pm { z }^{ * }\sqrt { \dfrac { ({ \hat { p } }_{ 1 })(1-{ \hat { p } }_{ 1 }) }{ { n }_{ 1 } } +\dfrac { { \hat { (p } }_{ 2 })({ 1-\hat { p } }_{ 2 }) }{ { n }_{ 2 } } }$$

Note that the standard deviation for the difference of two proportions is given on the AP formula sheet.

We can use process of elimination to solve for this. To find the critical value for $98\%$, look at the $t$-distribution critical value table and look directly above $98\%$. We can see that for $98\%$, the critical value is $2.33$. Therefore, we can eliminate Choices 'D' and 'E'.

Choice 'A' is incorrect, because the standard error (the square root component) is wrong.

Choice 'B' is incorrect because the interval was pooled. We pool in $2$ proportion $z$-tests, but not in $2$ proportion $z$-intervals.

Pooling is where we average the sample proportions. In this case, $(0.68 + 0.54)/2 = 0.61$; we can use that as our sample proportion.

Here is an alternative approach to solving this problem: If you do not know the formula, run the $2$ proportion $z$-interval on your calculator and see the interval. Then, do the calculations out for all the choices and see which one matches your interval you received on the calculator.
